Let $N(X,\delta)$ denote the maximum number of points $P_1,\ldots,P_n$ which can be chosen in a circle of radius $X$ such that\[\| \lvert P_i-P_j\rvert \| \geq \delta\]for all $1\leq i<j\leq n$. (Here $\|x\|$ is the distance from $x$ to the nearest integer.)

Is it true that, for any $0<\delta<1/2$, we have\[N(X,\delta)=o(X)?\]In fact, is it true that (for any fixed $\delta>0$)\[N(X,\delta)<X^{1/2+o(1)}?\]



The first conjecture was proved by S\'{a}rk\"{o}zy \cite{Sa76}, who in fact proved\[N(X,\delta) \ll \delta^{-3}\frac{X}{\log\log X}.\]Konyagin \cite{Ko01} proved the strong upper bound\[N(X,\delta) \ll_\delta N^{1/2}.\]See also [466] for lower bounds and [953] for a similar problem.




References


[Ko01] Konyagin, S. V., On the distances between points on the plane. Mat. Zametki (2001), 630-633.

[Sa76] S\'{a}rk\"{o}zy, A., On distances near integers. I, II. Studia Sci. Math. Hungar. (1976), 37-50, 105-111.
